reviewText:
Let me preface by saying that I don't generally like ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes.  I'm not a big fan of mindless gathering and grinding, or pay-to-win PvP.  And sometimes, I just like to be left alone.  But, since I enjoy the Conan mythos, I decided to give AoC a try.  Besides, at free-to-play, the price was right.

Age of Conan isn't revolutionary, but it certainly exceeded my expectations.  I joined the PvE server, and I have the luxury of playing it as a single-player game when I want to, and teaming up when I don't.  Even playing solo, levelling up occurs at a reasonable pace thanks to the hundreds of quests to discover and complete.  The character classes are balanced enough for PvE that you can choose one to suit your play style without having to worry about being too gimpy to advance.  And, what I like best of all, is that there are certain single-player Destiny Quests centering around the plot advancement of your own character.  Just imagine?  An MMO with a little plot.  So, all in all, there's really nothing to lose by taking a chance on the free play.

Just a warning, though - free play can be satisfying, but only up to level 80.  Even though 80 is max level, subscription players will continue to advance through an Alternate Advancement tree - so level 80 isn't really the end of your character's evolution.  But even if you play to 80 and don't choose to buy a subscription, just getting there can be worth the trip.

Gorgeous graphics, towering myths, singular bronze-age fantasy, grit and gore, rituals, magic and raw steel? Definitely. Then you learn how bugged instances, a loot table so broken it made T1-3 raiding almost useless, sickly f2p implementation, a toxic community, apathetic management and moderators, repeatedly sabotaged development teams and poor marketing also became part of this game's utterly unique experience. Thankfully, new content is coming out after years of stagnation, but it still feels like I'm watching something suffer.

This game is a pinnacle of potential, in drawing from rich lore, a great visual engine, one of the BEST melee combat systems ever created and an eager fan base, but ultimately has become a textbook study of bad leadership and worse followership. If you can somehow get past all of that, though, you may find the game beautiful and addicting as I have. I've been there since the beginning and I plan to be there until they pull the plug, but I'll always know it could have been something much sweeter, and for a short time early on, it was.

AoC is dead. Long live AoC.

CONs

Can be a fun..... if a bit clunky(the ui is horrible)... single player experience.  But if you want to play with friends, you can forget it.  Like many games, this has went with the horribly idiotic 'servers within servers' shard style idea, where there are multiple 'instances' even for the main world.  (Honestly, we've seen MMO's put the ENTIRE world on a single server, why do we have to deal with shards?)

This is a workable albeit annoying idea in any game that does it, but at least in those other games, you can easily change the instance, in this one.. not so.. you can ONLY change instances at a resurrection point/graveyard.  And you HAVE to change instances every time you enter a new area as a member of a team.  Unlike most games, if you're a member of a team and enter into a new area, you are NOT put into the instance other team members are in. You are put into your own instance of the area and then have to switch... good luck switching when you have a team member enter an area that DOESN'T have a res point.

Then of course, there's the horribly annoying combat (which can luckily be gotten around by being a spellcaster).  Far too many MMO's these days are wanting to go the 'action' route, instead of the more strategically minded 'autoattack plus abilities' route.  If you want to melee in this game, you have a left attack, overhead attack, and right attack that must stay on your keyboard, along with any of your attack 'casts' that you want to use because they have to combo together to be useful.  Nice idea, love the combo thought, but the way it works out with plain attacks is just horrible.

Yes, the game is free-to-play, but one of the worst limiting ones I've seen, there's only two tiers (free and subscription) as opposed to the 3 tier most f2p's have. There IS multiple instances that you are not allowed into if you are free, so you most certainly do not have access to full content without subscribing, and a portion of your character advancement even is locked to you if you aren't a paying member.

On the good side, there is voice acting for npc's and the world so far feels right for the Conan universe.

Overall the game DOES have some interesting ideas, but their implimentation is terrible and I could honestly only recommend this game to someone if I absolutely hated them.

reviewText:
From just 5 hours of gameplay, I can tell you a lot about this game.

The graphics, even on High settings on my Alienware, are nearly as bad as WoW. What's supposed to be lush jungle looks like someone ♥♥♥♥ green and put a bunch of plants on top. The character models are the only thing that look half-decent, but the animations are stiff and repetative, and some of the character models don't even look that great.

The combat seems fresh at first, but sadly the innovative mechanics of attacking where your enemy isn't guarding just become dull and repetative. Your enemies give no indication that they are shifting their defense in a certain direction aside from the large arrows surrounding them when you target them. It's a mechanic that deserves a place in a far better game.

The rest of combat feels stiff and unpolished, like most of the game. There's many questionable design desicions- for example, when you move while holding a bow, your character holds the bow in one hand and the arrow in the other. This doesn't sound so bad- Until you realize the character holds said arrow like it's a sword in a ham-fisted grip.

The game does, however, have a large variety of weapons and armor, and most of it's not your usual fantasy WoWclone gear. There is a large selection of stats and styles to choose from.

Let's get this out of way. Yes, as a female character, you can run around topless. If you're a thirteen year old desperate for some poorly-rendered digital boobies, you might consider this a very cool feature. I like to think that the more adult people among us might at best shrug at this. If you really want to see digital ♥♥♥♥ that badly, go play Scarlet Blade. It's at least a finished game.

The UI is the most clunky and obtrusive UI I've ever seen in a MMO. It's sole function seems to be to break immersion and be difficult to navigate.

The other unique features in the game, climbing and sneaking, are ham-fisted and poorly implemented. You can only climb in select places that are so obvious they might as well have massive signs strapped to them, and sneaking detection is extremely irregular. I've walked directly in front of hostile guards during the day with them being completely clueless, and yet an enemy with his back turned to you at night is hyperaware and can aggro onto you  from 15 feet away.

While everyone is voice-acted, the actual voice-acting is so flat and emotionless it might have been better not to have voice-acted the game at all. It's like the actors were aware of how dull and flat the quests they were being asked to voice were and couldn't be bothered to give a ♥♥♥♥.

Conan: Unchained feels like a game in early beta in spite of being out for several years. It's obvious the devs didn't give much of a rat's ♥♥♥ about putting out a polished game and instead just relied on the Conan name to sell it.

TL;DR: Pros: bare ♥♥♥♥, a few interesing but poorly implemented mechanics, good selection of  weapons and armors. Cons: Graphics from the early 2000's, horrible UI, dull and repetative quests, flat and emotionless voice acting, horrible animations, generally unfinished game.

Final rating: 3 out of 10. A poor game.

reviewText: The only thing I really liked about this game was the graphics. Utterly stunning. I hated the charge up attacks and spells. I am a more instant action type MMOer like with EQ2 or WOW. You hit your spell and it goes off or you swing your axe and immediately it hits your enemy. The combos are ok but nothing I would rave about. It is a grindy game. I am not sure what others have done but I usually try to go through all the quests if I see them but the majority were kind of uninspiring to me. Getting to level 20 was good the first time but having to do that every toon. Not something I enjoyed. Again EQ2 or WOW let you start in any of the lower zones you wanted. I know this is not those games but other start areas would have been great. And they have had years to do this now. Overall this MMO does nothing more than the otehrs do for me and maybe does less. If you like the lore that much or I should say the theme of Conan then you probably will like this no matter what I say. But if you want something new and innovative that ANYONE can get into and enjoy then this is probably not for you. I did not play this much on Steam but bought it back in the beginning so I have hundreds of hours into it and still have my toons if I want to log in but I have not for many months now. I do like MMOs but ones that are easy to figure out, simple to play and have moderate challenge but not hard. I do not PVP so I have no opinion on that. I am giving this a thumbs down for my own opinion not saying I will never play it again to kill some time. If you just like MMOs in general try it out for free but if you are looking for something new well a change of scenery is all I can see with this. I thought LOTR would change my opinion of MMOs like this one but I really had the same reaction to it after leveling for a while. Just another pretty game but nothing to hold my interest.

Let me preface this by saying that I'm not a big MMORPG player. I've enjoyed a couple over the years (World of WarCraft, The Old Republic, Guild Wars 2) but I never got too into them and probably never invested more than a month of my time. I tell you this because perhaps Age of Conan does something groundbreaking or exceptionally well - for an MMO - that might just be lost on me.

Regardless, Age of Conan really disappointed me.

What initially drove me to try the game was the setting - a setting that I became familiar with through the two films from the 1980s among other things. It was my belief that the fantasy world of Conan was a grim and dark one filled to the brim with blood, gore, boobs, and brutality. Even though the game has earned an M rating though I really didn't see anything that justified it and the game world just didn't really feel like Conan.

Additionally the visual quality and design is just downright horrid. I know the game came out in 2008 but critics were still praising its awe-inspiring" graphics as recent as 2011. Character models and NPCs just look plastic and ill-designed (there's something seriously wrong with their eyes) and the environments give off that stale

reviewText:
Held off playing this MMO due to limited interest in conan theme but have been very pleasantly suprised.

Pros:

1.  Very creative professions and gameplay.

2.  Intelligent and interesting storyline and quests.  PvE not too hard once you figure it out but NOT a faceroll like so many other games.

3.  Interesting and challenging group instances.

4.  Zones look awesome for 2008 graphics I was very pleasantly suprised considering how claustrophobic TSW zones seemed at times.

5.  Community generally willing to group and help.  Occassional idiots but not toxic like so many other MMOs.

Cons:

1.  Some bugs.  Some basic gameplay functions not explaained or explained poorly.  But people will generally help you out.

2.  Graphic glitches in some zones.

3.  Limited support.  Very little new content being produced.

4.  not P2W but you will need buy the expansion pack and a subscription once you reach endgame to get any enjoyable content.

Overall i recommend if you are looking for a solid reasonably priced MMO.
